text:
-Somebody every day is losing
a spouse or a significant
other or someone dear to them.

Every day, every minute, it's
happening to someone.

I think the difference here is
that because it's such a

public thing, and because it
touched so many of us, that

it's something you just
can't escape.

He was actually at the
World Trade Center
that day for a meeting.

Ordinarily, he'd worked at the
Mercantile Exchange, so it was

unusual for him to be
in the building.
Caitlin had just turned four.

We had just come back
from an amazing
family vacation to Italy.

It was the best vacation, and
I'm so glad that we did it,

because it was just really two
weeks later is when he died.

-Do you want the mini
cutting board?
-No, that's good.

And then get that little
black knife.

If he had died of an illness,
or a car accident or

something, the people close to
you are going to remember.

But your neighbors aren't
going to remember.

And people that met you 10 years
ago or five years ago
aren't going to remember.

But with something like
this, guess what?
They remember.
And it makes it harder.

As touching as it is, and you
know that it's coming from a

good place, it just
makes it so hard.

And you see it in
the newspapers.
Everybody's gearing up for it.

It's like, even if you say, I'm
going to go to Florida,
you can't escape it.
It's just everywhere.

If somebody asks me, Iliana,
what's your favorite food,
what's my answer?
-Dessert.
-Dessert.

Caitlin, throughout all of
this, has been amazing.

-Technically, you're not even
allowed to have sugar, because
it's Tuesday.
-I know.
It's not a weekend.

The last thing that Thomas said
when I spoke to him that

day, because he actually did
get through to me, was take
care of Caitlin.

So, not that I never would, but
there's something about
that being his last words.
-What's your favorite color?
-Green.

-What's your second
favorite color?
-Blue.

-Why is it that everyone who
likes green likes blue?
-I don't know.

The thing that I was not
prepared for is, when that

four-year-old turned six, her
understanding is different.

And I'll never forget one day,
we're at the supermarket, and

we come out of the supermarket
and she's in the backseat in
her booster.

And all of a sudden I look back,
and she's got tears.

And I'm like, Caitlin, baby,
what's the matter?

And she goes, well, I
don't understand.

Were the guys on the plane-- why
weren't they looking where
they were driving?
Were they driving like this?

And that's when it hits you that
she doesn't understand,

because we didn't go into that
kind of detail about it not
being an accident.

I always refer to it
as an accident.

And so you get into a little
bit of that discussion.
And that's at six.

Then imagine what happens at
eight, and imagine what
happens at 10, and now at 14.
This was December 1, 2001.

So this was a month,
two months later.

Every couple of years, it's a
new little challenge, a new
little experience.
Those are interesting clouds.
-Mom.
-You just go whew, OK.

Fasten my seat belt, because
here it comes.

There are going to be times that
are going to be bumpy.
But we get through it.
We get through it.

See what I meant about the
frosting acting as the glue?

-I always knew that the frosting
was acting as a glue.

I just didn't know how much
it was acting as a glue.

-See how when you don't have
any frosting there?
